intro: Galium radulifolium, commonly known as the mountain wood-sorrel, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its small, trifoliate leaves and clusters of white or pink flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest understories and rocky slopes. Its stems are often hairy, and it produces capsule fruits that contain several seeds. Galium radulifolium is adapted to cool, humid climates and is often found in mountainous regions.
